prompt.p: A 66-year-old woman is found collapsed at home by her carer. No other history is available. On admission her pulse is 135 beats/min and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. Results of her blood tests are shown below.
What is the most appropriate treatment?

modalFeedback.p: Option A (0.9% saline 1000mL stat) is Correct. Fluid resuscitation is the vital first step – these patients are often significantly volume deplete and require often quite aggressive fluid resuscitation. Saline is preferred in general as first line against haemodynamic parameters but invasive central venous pressure monitoring may be required.

Option B (Actrapid 1 U/h IV) is Incorrect. Careful insulin therapy and attention to the risk of venous thromboembolism are the mainstays of treatment once correction of the circulating volume has begun.

Option C 9Actrapid 10 U/h IV) is Incorrect. This is hyperosmolar non-ketotic coma. As rapid restoration of normoglycaemia may produce cerebral oedema, low doses of insulin are used in the first instance.

Option D (Actrapid 10 U SC stat) is Incorrect. This is hyperosmolar non-ketotic coma. As rapid restoration of normoglycaemia may produce cerebral oedema, low doses of insulin are used in the first instance.
Option E (Urgent dialysis) is Incorrect. This is not required at this point – moreover, attempting dialysis in a volume-deplete patient may cause significant haemodynamic instability.
